occurrences.line_text: Both flames and tempest: with which growen great,
And tottred like two towres, which through a tempest quooke.
Nought may abide the tempest of his yre,
Ne once to breath a while their angers tempest ceast.
In a great tempest; that in such distresse,
Like him that being long in tempest tost,
When foggy mistes, or cloudy tempests haue
And huge Orion, that doth tempests still portend.
A Fter long stormes and tempests ouerblowne,
But he that had like tempests often tride,
From all the tempests of these worldly seas,
Tempestuous fortune hath spent all her spight,
And calme the sea of their tempestuous spight,
Huge sea of sorrow, and tempestuous griefe,
Slow Peneus, and tempestuous Phasides,
Cruell Typhaon, whose tempestuous rage
With stormes of fortune and tempestuous fate,
Which doe the temple of the Gods support,
As it some Gyeld or solemne Temple weare:
Great Venus Temple is describ'd,
That was a temple faire and auncient,
The temple of great Venus, that is hight
Not that same famous Temple of Diane,
Into the inmost Temple thus I came,
That with the steme thereof the Temple swet,
But thus brake forth, that all the temple it did fill.
But forth I led her through the Temple gate,
Vnto whose temple when as Britomart
Was thence by them into the Temple led;
To rise through all the Temple sodainely,
That all the Temple put in ieopardy
That all the Temple did with terrour fill;
That euen the Temple, wherein she was plast,
To rub her temples, and to chaufe her chin,
And rubd his temples, and each trembling vaine;
And altars vnto him, and temples lent,
T'employ her puissaunce to his reskew,
To temporize is not from truth to swerue,
In whom great rule of Temp'raunce goodly doth appeare.
Oft tempred is (quoth she) with muchell smart:
Is meetest med'cine, tempred with sweet voice;
Tempred with grace, and goodly modesty,
Ministreth matter fit, which tempred right
But glauncing on the tempred mettall, brast
The same she tempred with fine Mercury,
Tempred with sternesse and stout maiestie,
Then running water, tempred with his teares,
Nathlesse that Dame so well them tempred both,
Tempred with Adamant amongst the same,
And tempred for the time her present heauinesse.
Yet tempred with some maiestie imperiall.
But by her tempred without griefe or gall,
So well was tempred, that for all his maine,
Tempred so well, but more admyr'd the stroke
The tempred steele did not into his braynepan byte.
A thousand sowres hath tempred with one sweet,
But hasty heat tempring with sufferance wise,
With fowle words tempring faire, soure gall with hony sweet.
Tempring the passion with aduizement slow,
But fairely tempring fond desire subdewd,
And coy lookes tempring with loose dalliance;
To proue his sense, and tempt her faigned truth.
But ioyd weake wemens hearts to tempt, and proue
For daring tempt the Queene of heauen to sin;
Her constant hart did tempt with diuerse guile:
To tempt the cause it selfe for to bewray;
Would tempt his guest, to take thereof assay:
That it would tempt a man to touchen there:
That all men feare to tempt his billowes strong,
Great store of treasure, therewith him to tempt;
And breaking forth, dare tempt the deepest flood,
To tempt such steps, where footing was so ill:
Is by him tempted, & led downe,
And warlike Caesar, tempted with the name
Daily he tempted her with this or that,
But he was nothing mou'd, nor tempted therewithall.
Till thou haue tride againe, & tempted him more neare.
O who may not with gifts and words be tempted?
Would not be tempted to such villenie,
And closely tempted with their craftie spyes;
But the good man, nought tempted with the offer
Ah Dame (quoth he) thou temptest me in vaine,
So tempting her still to pursue the pray,
Ten thousand kindes of creatures, partly male
In which ten thousand sorts of punishment
Me liefer were ten thousand deathes priefe,
Ten times so much be numbred francke and free.
Ascending by ten steps of Alablaster wrought.
Mo[N]Gst thousand dangers, & ten thousand magick mights.
Who long before the ten yeares siege of Troy,
Ten thousand wayes he cast in his confused thought.
Ten thousand thankes did yeeld her for her meed,
Besides ten thousand monsters foule abhor'd
Ten thousand fishes play, and decke his pleasant streame.
Ten daies (quoth he) he graunted hath of grace,
For if I liue till those ten daies haue end,
Since I was ten yeares old, now growen to stature strong.
After I had ten yeares my selfe excluded
Androgeus and Tenantius, pictures of his might.
Next him Tenantius raigned, then Kimbeline,
Sought with his raskall routs t'enclose them round,
They two enough t'encounter an whole Regiment.
Which when he spyde vpon the earth t'encroch,
Ne ought, that did to his aduauncement tend,
And tend our charges with obeisance meeke:
She warned them to tend their safeties well,
Did call diuine, that doth by Chester tend;
That when as time to Artegall shall tend,
They mote the better tend to their deuotion.
Vpon the thrones of mortall Princes tend,
To tend them well. So forth he went his way,
But with his clownish hands their tender wings
And fram'd of liquid ayre her tender partes
Both for her noble bloud, and for her tender youth.
My tender sides in this rough rynd embard,
To haue attonce deuour'd her tender corse:
Her tender brest in bitter teares all night,
In tender flesh, that streames of bloud down flow,
Doth weepe full sore, and sheddeth tender teares:
And euery tender part for feare does shake:
They in compassion of her tender youth,
For all he taught the tender ymp, was but
That cruell word her tender hart so thrild,
And euery tender part does tosse and turne:
And almost rent her tender hart in tway;
Whose tender locks do tremble euery one
Had charge the tender Orphans of the dead
There as thou slepst in tender swadling band,
Yet scratch my sonne, or rend his tender hand?
That seemd her tender heart was rent in twaine,
His litle hands, and tender ioynts embrew;
In vertuous lore to traine his tender youth,
With whom from tender dug of commune nourse,
Her daintie limbes aboue her tender hips,
Whose tender bud to blossome new began,
Their tender buds or leaues to violate,
Who taking it out of her tender hond,
And on his tender lips the downy heare
When first her tender hart was with his beautie smit.
I taken was from nourses tender pap,
Her tender babe, it seeing safe appeare,
And with sharpe fits thy tender hart oppresseth sore.
Their tender feet vpon the stony ground:
Tho vp him taking in their tender hands,
The point of pitty perced through her tender hart.
But from her louing side the tender babes to take.
Nor wicked beasts their tender buds did crop,
Ah, how the fearefull Ladies tender hart
Her tender waste was wound, adowne gan fall,
About their tender loynes to knit the same;
Could stay, but to the tender flesh it went,
And eft gan into tender teares to melt.
Her tender hart in peeces would diuide:
Ne feeles the thorns and thickets pricke her tender toes.
Whose tender heart the faire Belphebe had,
Who seeing his sad plight, her tender heart
Her tender heart, and made refraine from meat,
Sometime with tender teares to let her goe,
Thus whilst his stony heart with tender ruth
Who round about her tender wast it fitted well.
The more thereby her tender hart was payned.
So faire and tender, without staine or spot,
First there came Pittie, with full tender hart,
With the neare touch whereof in tender hart
There came two Springals of full tender yeares,
Like as a tender Rose in open plaine,
Nor spilt the blossome of my tender yeares
And in his tender armes her forced vp to stay.
Made in his tender flesh, but whole them all he found.
With tender ruth for her vnworthy griefe:
But shedding few soft teares from tender eyne,
To see her sore lament, and bite her tender lip.
And as ye soft and tender are by kynde,
So be ye soft and tender eeke in mynde;
Her tender sides, her bellie white and clere,
Beside them fed, and nipt the tender bloomes:
Their tender flocks, now being fully fed,
And seeing them, for tender pittie wept:
No lesse did tender the faire Pastorell,
More deare then life she tendered, whose flowre
Who no lesse carefully her tendered,
For first, next after life, he tendered her good.
They lay therein those corses tenderly,
He much reioyst, and courd it tenderly,
To take him from his steed full tenderly,
Their fleecy flowres they tenderly did steepe,
She straightly straynd, and colled tenderly,
T'endow her sonne with threasure and rich store,
Seeing his honor, which she tendred chiefe,
Sith ye thus farre haue tendred my poore case,
To know, and them t'enlarge with long extent,
Commaunding Proteus straight t'enlarge the mayd,
And to my tunes thy second tenor rayse,
And bad tell on the tenor of his plaint;
Ne ought mote make him change his wonted tenor,
Thence to depart for further aide t'enquire:
T'enquire of them, whether by force, or sleight,
Both were full loth to leaue that needfull tent,
Then Talus forth issuing from the tent,
Then forth came Artegall out of his tent,
That night Sir Artegall did cause his tent
T'entrap vnwary fooles in their eternall bales.
For to maligne, t'enuie, t'vse shifting slight,
T'enure them selues to sufferaunce thereby
That now we foolish men that prayse gin eke t'enuy.
Therefore by Termagaunt thou shalt be dead.
Whom all men term'd Knight of the Hebene speare,
That is the terme prescribed by the spell.
As time in her iust terme the truth to light should bring.
And said, The terme of life is limited,
Soone as the terme of those six yeares shall cease,
And guide the heauenly causes to their constant terme.
Nay but the terme (said he) is limited,
Tho when the terme is full accomplishid,
Which still increast, till she her terme had full outgone.
Then since (quoth she) the terme of each mans life
It seemed, him to terme the saluage knight.
For since the terme of fourteene hundred fyeres,
Me iustly terme, that to this shame am brought,
Ne for aduantage terme to entertaine,
For that the terme approching fast, required speed.
A wofull dame ye haue me termed well;
And with her gealous termes his open eares abused.
With wounding words and termes of foule repriefe
(Quoth he) knowes best the termes established;
Here heaped vp with termes of loue vnkind,
And stablish termes betwixt both their requests,
In foule reproch, and termes of vile despight,
And into termes of open outrage brust,
Her list in strifull termes with him to balke,
And said, Sir knight, these idle termes forbeare,
And friends to termes of gentle truce entize,
So tickle be the termes of mortall state,
Then with dishonorable termes her to entreat.
With termes of loue and lewdnesse dissolute;
And there with many gentle termes her faire besought.
Yet Blandamour with termes of foule despight,
With which vaine termes so much they did the[m]; moue,
And with lewd termes their louers to deface.
With such smooth termes her error I abusd,
To better termes of myldnesse did entreat,
With bitter taunts, and termes of vile disgrace.
Ne would be taught with any termes, to lerne
Then termes to entertaine of common guize,
For her no other termes should euer tie
Not onely into bitter termes forth brust,
Ne time would giue, nor any termes aby,
From that they most affect, and in due termes containe.
With all the euill termes and cruell meane,
With bitter termes of shamefull infamy;
But tell, Sir Terpin, ne let you amate
Therefore Sir Terpin from you lightly throw
Sir Terpin, from her direfull doome acquit,
Together with sir Terpin all that night:
Saues Terpine from the gallow tree,
Sir Terpine, haplesse man, what make you here?
But Terpine borne to'a more vnhappy howre,
For neither doth thy face terrestriall shew,
Far passing th'hight of men terrestriall;
Ne him commit to graue terrestriall,
To Elfes, but sprong of seed terrestriall,
Whose shapes seem'd not like to terrestriall boyes,
With which and other spelles like terrible,
But yet so sterne and terrible in sight,
His portaunce terrible, and stature tall,
Large were his limbes, and terrible his looke,
No whit lesse faire, then terrible in fight:
And teares it all with terrible mischance.
And there came Stoure with terrible aspect,
Did them assault with terrible allarme,
Their cruell strokes and terrible affright;
And manhood rare, but terrible and stearne
For he was sterne, and terrible by nature,
There he tormenteth her most terribly,
So terribly his dreadfull strokes did thonder,
And downe he fell, with dread of shame sore terrifide.
That in short space their foes they haue quite terrifide.
That vgly shape so sore her terrifide,
He blest himselfe, as one sore terrifide,
Yet him nought terrifide, that feared nothing ill.
Who nought was terrifide, but greater courage tooke.
That terrifide his foes, and armed him,
Could terrifie from Fortunes faire adward:
As if he with his lookes would all men terrifie.
That liuing creature it would terrify,
His hand, that trembled, as one terrifyde;
He met a Dwarfe, that seemed terrifyde
Did spread their rule through all the territories,
Let now abate the terror of your might,
Might once abide the terror of that blast,
And trembling terror did his hart apall,
Doth rore at them in vaine, and with great terror raue.
That to this day for terror of his fame,
Murmure of winde, her terror hath encreast;
And awfull terror deepe into him strooke,
At sight thereof she was with terror queld,
And with vnwonted terror halfe affray,
Through the sad terror of so dreadfull fate,
Their forces furie, and their terror slake;
With dreadfull terror, and with fell intent;
With flaming sword in hand his terror more to breed.
Confused, did the ayre with terror fill,
Do meete, that with the terrour of the shocke
That all the earth for terrour seemd to shake,
And peoples harts with awfull terrour tye,
Both glorious brightnesse, and great terrour bred;
That all the ayre with terrour filled wide,
The cloudes before him fled for terrour great,
And was for terrour more, all armd in shyning bras.
Whose carkases, for terrour of his name,
Troubled with terrour and vnquiet iarre,
For terrour of the tortures manifold,
And manly terrour mixed therewithall,
That with so troublous terrour they were all dismayde.
And his base thought with terrour and with aw
That with the terrour of their fierce affret,
Both with great ruth and terrour she was smit,
And with the terrour of his countenance bold
There with huge terrour, to be more ydrad,
That all the Temple did with terrour fill;
With trembling ioynts, as he for terrour shooke;
Sir Terwin hight, that well himselfe aduaunst
And now made better speed, t'escape his feared foe.
To seeke by flight her fellowship t'eschew,
A booke, wherein his Saueours testament
As she bequeathd in her last testament;
That present were to testifie the case.
Yet shall it not by none be testifyde.
His dwelling is; there Tethys his wet bed
Oft soust in swelling Tethys saltish teare,
Into great Tethys bosome, where they hidden lye.
Old Tethys, th'oldest two of all the rest,
Cold Coloquintida, and Tetra mad,
Well seemes t'exceede the powre of patience,
T'expresse the meaning of the inward mind,
T'expresse some part of that great equipage,
T'expresse his passions, which his reason did empeach.
But he him selfe vppon th rich doth tyrannize.
Ioyous Thalia, goodly Amphitrite,
Next faire Aglaia, last Thalia merry:
His auncient parents, namely th'auncient Thame.
But Thame was stronger, and of better stay;
Or Arts, but Oxford thine doth Thame most glorify.
Where Thames doth the Medway wedd,
Betwixt the Medway and the Thames agreed.
Long had the Thames (as we in records reed)
Of wealthy Thamis washed is along,
The noble Thamis, with all his goodly traine,
With such an one was Thamis beautifide;
His way still vnder ground, till Thamis he ouertake.
Did on the Thamis attend, and waited well
For those same Islands, seeming now and than,
Well tride in all thy Ladies troubles than,
But of her loue too lauish (litle haue she thancke.)
Sir Calepine her thanckt, yet inly wroth
Yet litle losse it were, and mickle thanke,
Gan greatly thanke his host and his good wife;
She thanked them in her disdainefull wise,
And humbly thanked him a thousand sith,
They tooke it well, and thanked God for all,
As tokens of her thankefull mind beseene,
To shew her thankefull mind and meaning faine,
Which she receiuing with meete thankefulnesse,
Which she accepts, with thankes, and goodly gree,
Great thankes and goodly meed to that good syre,
And thousand thankes him yeelds for all his paine.
And to that Damzell thankes gaue for reward.
But with glad thankes, and vnreproued truth,
To get small thankes, and therewith many blames,
Ten thousand thankes did yeeld her for her meed,
Praysing their god, and yeelding him great thankes,
And thousand thankes him yeeld, that had so well
Can yeeld great thankes for such her curtesie,
Who with right humble thankes him goodly greeting,
And yeeld great thankes for their so goodly deed,
With all due thankes, and dutifull respect,
And thousand thankes to Calidore for fee
Yet no lesse thankes to you for your good will.
That thankfull guerdon may to you repay.
Should die vnknown, & buried be in thanklesse thought.
That hast a thanklesse seruice on thee ta'ne,
That will not vse his gifts for thanklesse nigardise.
And thrise three hundred thanks for my good partes
Her selfe most gratefull shew'd, & heaped thanks repayd.
With thanks to Bellamour and Claribell,
But thankt be God, and her encrease so euermore.
Then God she praysd, and thankt her faithfull knight,
But thankt be God, and your good hardiment,
She humbly thankt him for that wondrous grace,
Conuay to be recur'd. She thankt him deare,
Yet he them all refusd, though thankt her as a frend.
A thousand times him thankt, that had her death preuented.
Whom that most noble Briton Prince so long
That I must rue his vndeserued wrong:
Faire Venus sonne, that with thy cruell dart
At that good knight so cunningly didst roue,
That glorious fire it kindled in his hart,
To thinke of that true glorious type of thine,
Yet armes till that time did he neuer wield:
For whose sweete sake that glorious badge he wore,
That greatest Gloriana to him gaue,
That greatest Glorious Queene of Faerie lond,
Vnder a vele, that wimpled was full low,
As one that inly mournd: so was she sad,
So pure and innocent, as that same lambe,
Of ancient Kings and Queenes, that had of yore
Till that infernall feend with foule vprore
That lasie seemd in being euer last,
That euery wight to shrowd it did constrain,
That promist ayde the tempest to withstand:
Did spred so broad, that heauens light did hide,
Faire harbour that them seemes; so in they entred arre.
And Poets sage, the Firre that weepeth still,
They cannot finde that path, which first was showne,
That makes them doubt, their wits be not their owne:
That which of them to take, in diuerse doubt they been.
Till that some end they finde or in or out,
That path they take, that beaten seemd most bare,
That path they take, that beaten seemd most bare,
Be well aware, quoth then that Ladie milde,
Soone as that vncouth light vpon them shone,
Much daunted with that dint, her sence was dazd,
That hand or foot to stirre he stroue in vaine:
That when he heard, in great perplexitie,
That soone to loose her wicked bands did her constraine.
Which stunck so vildly, that it forst him slacke
That welnigh choked with the deadly stinke,
That from their noyance he no where can rest,
That from her body full of filthie sin
That detestable sight him much amazde,
His Ladie seeing all, that chaunst, from farre
Well worthy be you of that Armorie,
And henceforth euer wish, that like succeed it may.
That path he kept, which beaten was most plaine,
And often knockt his brest, as one that did repent.
Who faire him quited, as that courteous was:
Silly old man, that liues in hidden cell,
That wasteth all this countrey farre and neare.
In which that wicked wight his dayes doth weare:
That such a cursed creature liues so long a space.
And well I wote, that of your later fight
The Sunne that measures heauen all day long,
(Quoth then that aged man;) the way to win
So with that godly father to his home they went.
Far from resort of people, that did pas
For that old man of pleasing wordes had store,
A bold bad man, that dar'd to call by name
So sound he slept, that nought mought him awake.
Shooke him so hard, that forced him to speake.
He that the stubborne Sprites can wisely tame,
A fit false dreame, that can delude the sleepers sent.
Had made a Lady of that other Spright,
That weaker sence it could haue rauisht quight:
Now when that ydle dreame was to him brought,
Vnto that Elfin knight he bad him fly,
And that new creature borne without her dew,
He taught to imitate that Lady trew,
That nigh his manly hart did melt away,
And to him playnd, how that false winged boy,
To be the chastest flowre, that ay did spring
Most like that virgin true, which for her knight him took.
Or the blind God, that doth me thus amate,
What frayes ye, that were wont to comfort me affrayd?
Her doubtfull words made that redoubted knight
That for my sake vnknowne such griefe vnto you grew.
And fed with words, that could not chuse but please,
Much grieu'd to thinke that gentle Dame so light,
That troublous dreame gan freshly tosse his braine,
With that misformed spright he backe returnd againe.
That was in Ocean waues yet neuer wet,
To all, that in the wide deepe wandring arre:
Had warned once, that Phoebus fiery carre
Full enuious that night so long his roome did fill.
That feigning dreame, and that faire-forged Spright
That feigning dreame, and that faire-forged Spright
Eftsoones he tooke that miscreated faire,
And that false other Spright, on whom he spred
His wanton dayes that euer loosely led,
That here wex old in sleepe, whiles wicked wights
Where that false couple were full closely ment
But hardly was restreined of that aged sire.
And for her Dwarfe, that wont to wait each houre;
Then gan she waile and weepe, to see that woefull stowre.
That him to follow was but fruitlesse paine;
That had such might ouer true meaning harts;
That of himselfe he oft for feare would quake,
Of that good knight, his late beguiled guest:
And hope to winne his Ladies heart that day,
That daunted with their forces hideous,
Do meete, that with the terrour of the shocke
Curse on that Crosse (quoth then the Sarazin)
That keepes thy body from the bitter fit;
Had not that charme from thee forwarned it:
That a large share it hewd out of the rest,
So hugely stroke, that it the steele did riue,
Whither the soules do fly of men, that liue amis.
And tell, both who ye be, and who that tooke your part.
Before that angry heauens list to lowre,
Was, (O what now auaileth that I was!)
He that the wide West vnder his rule has,
